abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Parana Biodiversity
            Project for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to global environment outcome was
            moderate, the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory,
            and the Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the success of
            the project, even considering the difficulties that emerged
            along its development, strongly suggests that there is an
            added value in trying to promote this innovative approach.
            Moreover, it could be further expanded by including more
            government agencies, Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs)
            with different, complementary profiles, the academic and
            research, as well as other relevant sectors of the civil
            society. Even if challenging and difficult to implement,
            developing a better and wider coordination and integration
            between government sectors and other non-governmental
            institutions is becoming an urgent need in face of the
            growing environmental problems that affect the whole planet.
            Given its innovative and somewhat experimental nature, it is
            important to bear in mind that even errors, difficulties and
            unexpected outcomes resulting from this project provide very
            useful experience and insight applicable to future projects
            of similar intersectoral and transversal nature. Problems
            related with project administration that emerged along this
            project suggest that as projects become more complex and
            intersectoral; conflicts of this nature are more likely to
            arise. Therefore, it will be important in future projects to
            resource to all the available mechanisms that may contribute
            to eliminate beforehand as many potential difficulties of
            this kind as possible. At the time when the project was
            planned, the State Government of Parana had showed a strong
            commitment and support for environmental protection.
            Accordingly, the project was designed under the assumption
            that the State authorities will support innovative
            approaches and their effective implementation. After
            elections in 2002 the new authorities did not embrace the
            government commitment with the same emphasis. As a result,
            project implementation suffered both administrative delays
            and changes in priorities that affected the normal
            development of planned activities in several components.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Parana Biodiversity Project :
            final eligibility report and recommendation

abstracts.cdata!:
This report follows on the previous
            inspection panel report entitled "Report and
            Recommendation - BRAZIL: Parana Biodiversity Project (GEF TF
            051 007)," dated September 11, 2006 (Report No.
            INSP/R2006-0005), and distributed to the Executive Directors
            and Alternates on September 21, 2006, and contains the
            Panel's final recommendation on whether the issues
            raised in the request for inspection warrant an
            investigation. The report contains the panel's final
            recommendation on whether an investigation of the issues
            raised in the request for inspection is warranted. The panel
            understands the concerns of the requesters for the reasons
            noted below. The Requesters, the Government and Bank
            Management agree that the Araucaria Mixed Forest remnants in
            advanced successional stage are very rare and now reduced to
            about 60,000 ha or 0.8 percent of their original area,
            although there are estimates that the exact area may be a
            little higher or lower. They note that the threat of the
            complete destruction of these remnants is very high and that
            the highest priority for biodiversity conservation in the
            State should be to prevent their destruction. The Panel
            notes that after the Request for Inspection to the Panel, a
            number of actions have taken place to address the
            Requesters' concerns about the implementation of the
            Project. The Technical Audit, conducted in September and
            October 2006, proposed increased attention to conserving the
            remaining remnants of the forests, especially the Araucaria
            forests. The State Authorities in Parana subsequently
            prepared an Action Plan to develop additional measures to
            support biodiversity conservation. In light of the above
            considerations, the Panel does not recommend an
            investigation of whether the Bank has complied with its
            operational policies and procedures.

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Paper informs the Board of
            the second-order restructuring for the Brazil Parana
            Biodiversity Project. The Beneficiary has requested a
            reallocation of funds between Grant Agreement categories
            together with amendments to the Grant Agreement in order to
            improve project implementation and address the issues raised
            by the recently completed Technical Audit included in the
            Bank's management response to the Inspection Panel. The
            original objective of the Project is not modified and the
            associated outcome targets remain the same, with the
            exception of some operational adjustments that do not
            materially change the expectations of the results that the
            project would achieve.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Parana Biodiversity Project -
            Inspection Panel Report and Recommendations including
            request for inspection and management response to the
            request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The Parana Biodiversity Project for
            Brazil (PBP) aims at: (a) to support biodiversity
            conservation and sustainable natural resource management in
            the Biodiversity Corridors with a view to protect two highly
            threatened ecoregions in the Recipient's territory: the
            Inland Atlantic Rainforest and the Araucaria Forest regions;
            and (6) to design and implement a model for improving
            biodiversity conservation in the Recipient's territory.
            The Panel recommends to the Board of Executive Directors
            that it approve the Panel's proposal to refrain from
            issuing a recommendation at this time on whether an
            investigation is warranted in this case, but rather await
            further developments on the matters raised in the Request
            for Inspection. The Panel expects to be able to make a
            determination by February 2007 as to whether to recommend an investigation.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Projeto Paraná biodiversidade :
            relatório preliminar de auditoria técnica

abstracts.cdata!:
This report aims to present and reflect
            on the performance of the Paraná Biodiversity Project in its
            design, implementation and execution context, taking into
            account a retrospective analysis and forecasts in order for
            future adjustments and improvements performance. The Paraná
            Biodiversity Project represents an innovative approach to
            regional biodiversity conservation and its integration into
            the processes of sustainable rural development and might
            become an important model for the country. The
            implementation process is set to expand the interpretation
            of the concept of Biodiversity Conservation. The project
            still has problems concerning the interpretation of the idea
            of biodiversity. This idea needs to be discussed and to
            develop a smooth coordination between all institutions and
            to execute and represent civil society. For this, it is
            vital that there are open channels of permanent dialogue and
            leveling concepts, functions and mechanisms for
            implementation. The implementation of the design has so far
            been subjected to a number of interruptions that effectively
            limit their real-time implementation and has created a
            negative overall performance.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Parana Biodiversity (GEF) Project
            : request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
On July 10, 2006, the Inspection Panel
            (the "Panel") received a Request for Inspection
            (the "Request"), dated June 23, 2006, related to
            the Brazil: Parana Biodiversity Project (the
            "Project") financed under the Global Environmental
            Facility (GEF Trust Fund No 051007). The Request was
            submitted by a non-governmental organization (NGO) based in
            the State of Parana, Brazil. The Requesters state that the
            approval of the Project carried "an unprecedented and
            very positive expectation that would generate actions"
            aimed at preserving the State of Parana's biodiversity.
            According to the Request, the conservation of the biomass of
            the Araucaria and the Atlantic Forest is of "great
            priority" in the State of Parana, because same are now
            reduced to 0.8 percent of its original area. However,
            according to the Request, "methodological changes"
            made to Project implementation after approval have resulted
            in a change of Project activities, which will prevent the
            achievement of the original Project objectives, and will
            worsen the current situation. Until further notice, all
            communications with the Requesters in connection with the
            Request will be sent to the Executive Secretary of the NGO
            Network of the Atlantic Forest, whom the Requesters
            appointed as their representative. After receiving the
            Management response, the Panel will, determine whether the
            Request meets the eligibility criteria set out in paragraphs
            12 to 14 [of the Resolution], and shall make a
            recommendation to the Executive Directors as to whether the
            matter should be investigated.

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Parana Biodiversity Conservation
            (GEF) Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The nature of the Parana Biodiversity
            Conservation Project, will promote environmental improvement
            actions, focused on the conservation, and protection of the
            native biodiversity. Nonetheless, because of existing
            interactions between the project, and other developmental
            activities in the State of Parana, the following shall be
            excluded within project implementation: fumigation; planting
            of crop species not native to the soil; fertilizer and/or
            pesticide spraying; dredging or drainage of natural
            habitats; river flows diversification; and, pervasive land
            uses. Mitigation measures shall forbear cultural and
            religious sites, while other restrictions include land
            acquisition, disposal of toxic wastes, and, vegetative
            degradation. Natural resource management within the project,
            include vegetative propagation of autochthonous species,
            including terracing, or protective plant barriers to prevent
            soil erosion; groundwater protection, and appropriate water
            distribution; and, woodland restoration to attract natural
            fauna. Project agro-ecological modules will be promoted
            within communities (which includes individual properties),
            favoring alternatives to reduce the risk of natural resource
            degradation, i.e., crop rotation, and mixed agricultural and
            livestock production, including the maintenance of genetic
            diversity. The environmental regional criteria will be
            enforced at the municipal, administrative, and micro-basins
            levels, in compliance with the regulations set by the
            Regional Commission, formalized by a municipal protocol
            intended to cooperate with project activities, while
            identified micro-basins will undergo the biodiversity
            conservation management as set by the project components.

docna.cdata!:
Brazil - Parana Biodiversity Conservation
            (GEF) Project : environmental assessment

Brazil - Parana Biodiversity
            Conservation (GEF) Project : environmental assessment

1766942.subsc: Agricultural extension and research,Sub-national government administration,Central government administration,General agriculture, fishing and forestry sector

abstracts.cdata!:
The Parana Biodiversity Project will
            support the development of a sustainable natural resource
            management, in two highly threatened eco-regions - the
            Brazilian Inland Atlantic Rainforest, and Araucaria Forest -
            through the design, and implementation of a model for
            improving biodiversity conservation in the State. Project
            components include: 1) education and capacity building,
            aimed at sensitizing the population of Parana State in the
            importance of biodiversity conservation, mobilizing it to
            support the process of regaining the quality of ecosystems,
            and enable the participation of project implementing
            agencies, beneficiaries, and stakeholders. Eight capacity
            building courses, and specialized training are projected for
            implementing agencies to assume management, fiscal, and
            legal enforcement responsibilities; and, courses for the
            dissemination of project concepts, and practices are
            intended to target rural communities to participate in
            agro-ecological subprojects. Educational, and promotional
            materials will be provided to support the above mentioned
            courses, and agricultural extension activities; 2)
            biodiversity management, and improved administration of
            seven protected areas at the core of the geographic
            corridors, through macro-planning to identify
            micro-catchments, to then sequence the development of
            management plans, with the assistance of consultants,
            pubic-private partnerships, and nongovernmental
            organizations. Equipment supply, and infrastructure
            activities are to be included, to support sustainable
            financial sufficiency, through eco-tourism, and handicrafts
            development; 3) establish monitoring and evaluation quality
            criteria for biodiversity conservation, by refining
            licensing norms for environmental activities, and supporting
            municipal fiscal decentralization; and, 4) project
            administration practices to coordinate the central,
            regional, and municipal management committees, and,
            strategic studies will focus on the consolidation of
            environmental legislation, and certification, as well as on
            the cost-benefit of environmental interventions.
